body: Can you elaborate on the difference you see with the second example? This performs identical to XTerm in my tests.

> Can you elaborate on the difference you see with the second example? This performs identical to XTerm in my tests.

With the second example, in Terminal.app on macOS, origin mode is re-enabled when restore cursor is called causing the line positioning to end up at 5, not 7.

> With the second example, in Terminal.app on macOS, origin mode is re-enabled when restore cursor is called causing the line positioning to end up at 5, not 7.

Can you share a screenshot? You mean line index 5/7? The "7" should be in line 2, while "Here" should be in 7.

> Can you share a screenshot? You mean line index 5/7? The "7" should be in line 2, while "Here" should be in 7. I see the problem, when you updated my example, you made `\u001B7` into `\e[B7` when it was meant to be `\e7`. This is what it was meant to be. Here you'll see the word "Here" end up on line 7 when it should end up on line 5 as restoring the cursor should restore the state of origin mode at the time of saving which means the cursor shouldn't be able to escape the scrollable region of lines 1 to 5. ```bash printf "\e[2J\e[1;5r\e[?6h\e7\e[?6l\e8\e[7HHere" ``` Below is a picture of the difference in output. The left is Alacritty with "Here" on line 7. The right is Terminal.app with "Here" on line 5.

The origin mode issue seems pretty clear, Alacritty is just missing a `GOTO 0,0` when entering origin mode.

The save/restore cursor is a little less obvious, because VT100 doesn't actually save the origin mode, so that's something that came at a later stage. Alacritty matches URxvt here so I'm inclined to keep it as-is, I don't think it should be a problem either way.

issue.title: Fix DECOM cursor motion
issue.body:
This fixes a missing `GOTO 0,0` when entering the terminal origin mode.

Closes #8636.

body:
If save cursor isn't saving the state of origin mode, and restore cursor isn't restoring the state of origin mode, does that mean if origin mode is enabled and the cursor position saved is outside of origin mode, that:
- the cursor will escape the scrollable region while origin mode is enabled
- the cursor will be clamped on its way back
- the cursor just don't move at all?

> VT100 doesn't actually save the origin mode

Yes it does. Later models used a slightly different algorithm, but they all save and restore origin mode.

As @BlackAsLight pointed out, if you don't restore the mode, you can end up with the cursor position out of bounds, potentially with negative coordinates. Although that's less of a problem for Alacritty, because it doesn't respect origin mode when reporting the position, so the coordinates are just incorrect, but at least still valid numbers.

> Yes it does. Later models used a slightly different algorithm, but they all save and restore origin mode.

By that you mean the actual VT100 I'd assume? I'm just going based off the documentation. This also matches URxvt's behavior, as stated previously.

> I'm just going based off the documentation.

Can you link to the documentation you're reading?
Thank you. Seems I was mistaking VT220 behaviour for VT100 behaviour.

> By that you mean the actual VT100 I'd assume?

Yes.

> I'm just going based off the documentation.

If you want to know all the terminal implementation details, you need to read the documentation that was intended for terminal developers, like DEC STD 070. The VT100 user guide isn't really adequate for this sort of thing.

> This also matches URxvt's behavior, as stated previously.

I know there are a quite a few terminals with this bug, so I don't think it's a big deal if you don't want to fix it. I just wanted you to be aware that it is actually a bug, and you're not matching the VT100 behavior.
